vision.notes: Catsharks possess vision, though it may be adapted for low-light conditions given their benthic and deep-water habitats. The New Zealand catshark is dark brown around the top with pale spots, suggesting visual camouflage and detection of contrast.

electroreception.notes: As members of the Carcharhiniformes order, it is inferred they possess electroreception capabilities using ampullae of Lorenzini to detect weak electrical fields, aiding in prey detection.

mechanoreception.notes: Likely possess a lateral line system for detecting vibrations and pressure changes in the water, common in sharks and important for detecting prey and navigating in their environment.

chemoreception.notes: Catsharks likely use chemoreception (smell and taste) to locate prey in the benthic environment.
